entry.title: Combined summary - Update on the Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
entry.summary:
The ongoing development within the Bitcoin community focuses on addressing and mitigating various vulnerabilities identified in the protocol, a movement initiated by Matt Corallo's Great Consensus Cleanup proposal in 2019. This proposal sought to enhance the security and efficiency of Bitcoin with several adjustments, such as invalidating small transactions to improve merkle tree integrity, refining script validation processes to reduce block validation times, and adjusting timestamp rules to avoid manipulation of difficulty adjustments. Following this proposal, extensive research and discussions have been undertaken to fully understand these vulnerabilities and devise appropriate solutions. These discussions have taken place on platforms like Delving and in private forums, allowing for an in-depth exploration of potential fixes.
The revised consensus cleanup proposal includes critical updates aimed at bolstering the Bitcoin network's security and functionality. Among these updates are mechanisms designed to counteract the timewarp attack by introducing a grace period for timestamp validity and combating the Murch-Zawy attack through restrictions on difficulty adjustment periods. Additionally, to address concerns over prolonged block validation times, it suggests implementing a cap on the number of legacy signature operations allowed per transaction. Further enhancements proposed include increasing merkle tree security by prohibiting transactions that serialize to exactly 64 bytes and modifying the nLockTime field requirements for coinbase transactions to prevent future redundancies in BIP30 validation. A draft Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) is currently being prepared to detail these specifications, marking a significant effort to strengthen the Bitcoin network against existing threats and ensure its robustness and longevity.
